abstract.p: Webster, NY, restaurant manager Michael Papapanu will trade anything on the menu for a share of Xerox common stock (S)

block.p: Given Xerox's recent troubles -- market share eroding, cash evaporating, management scrambling, rumors swirling -- it can be hard to find anyone on Wall Street willing to bet on its stock.
But in Webster, N.Y., a Rochester suburb, there is always a buyer. Michael Papapanu, who runs the Two M's Restaurant, will trade you anything on the menu for a share of Xerox common.
Given Xerox's recent troubles -- market share eroding, cash evaporating, management scrambling, rumors swirling -- it can be hard to find anyone on Wall Street willing to bet on its stock.
But in Webster, N.Y., a Rochester suburb, there is always a buyer. Michael Papapanu, who runs the Two M's Restaurant, will trade you anything on the menu for a share of Xerox common.

The Two M's is popular with workers at the Xerox plant just across Route 104, and Mr. Papapanu has seen the cares and woes spreading across his customers' faces. ''With so much pessimism about the company, I say I'll put food in your mouth for stock,'' Mr. Papapanu said. ''I am thinking positive.''

As with any offer for securities, though, wise customers do the math first. Based on Friday's close of $8.38 a share, trading a stake for a steak would be a fine bargain -- the T-bone at the Two M's usually goes for $12.95. But you'd be better off paying cash for the broiled scallops ($7.95).
